Content-Type: text/plain; charset=utf-8
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Hello Peter,

Yes it does make sense to try NEAT first, just to get a feel =
for this. The main 
reason I considered hyperNEAT is because the input data=
 would be planetary 
coordinates, of which is geometric in nature. The inpu=
ts should total no more 
than 40, this also includes inter-market forex dat=
a. Because future planetary 
information is known in advance this can be us=
ed in our forecasts.

Which source data Library do you feel is best for thi=
s type of task?

Peter 




________________________________
From: petar_ch=
ervenski <petar_chervenski@...>
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Fri, 5=
 November, 2010 7:37:57
Subject: [neat] Re: Financial trading with Hypernea=
t

=C2=A0 
Hi Peter, 

I'd suggest that you try regular NEAT first, HyperNE=
AT may not be neccessary. 
HyperNEAT is a good choice if the inputs are hun=
dreds or thousands in number 
and/or there is some obvious geometry in the =
input space that can be exploited 
by arranging the positions of the substr=
ate nodes. For financial applications 
I'd use a small set of inputs, but v=
ery preprocessed data, like what most good 
custom indicators do, and regul=
ar NEAT. 


Peter

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Wesley Tansey <tansey@...> =
wrote:
>
> Peter,
> 
> I think you'd be better off familiarizing yourself w=
ith the details of 
> how HyperNEAT works. Novelty Search is a different al=
gorithm altogether, 
> for a different class of problems. You probably shou=
ld familiarize 
> yourself with the HyperNEAT algorithm before trying to de=
sign an 
> experiment. The HyperNEAT user's page has a lot of really good 
=
> information: http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/hyperNEATpage/HyperNEAT.html
> 
> I'=
m not familiar with the EPlex's C++ framework, but SharpNEAT does 
> provid=
e a GUI. However, it's more of an engineer's GUI, designed to 
> visualize =
your experiment after you set it up in code. I tend to find it 
> easier to=
 just use SharpNEAT in a console application. I've written some 
> tutorial=
s on how to create a SharpNEAT experiment:
> 
>http://www.nashcoding.com/20=
10/07/17/tutorial-evolving-neural-networks-with-sharpneat-2-part-1/
>/
> 
>=
 Hope that helps.
> 
> Sincerely,
> Wesley
> 
> On 11/4/2010 10:14 AM, Pete=
r wrote:
> >
> > Westley,
> >
> > Thanks, Data presentation is quite import=
ant, I understand that 
> > HyperNEAT is design to accept 3D data source, I=
 can add any time frame 
> > also multple markets, to refect external marke=
t influences.
> >
> > Is there currently a GUI interface avilable to input =
and output data?
> > Is there any other considerations to take into account=
 with regards ? 
> > to data presentatation that I must adhere to?
> >
> > =
I notice from the links there is also a Novelty search Library 
> > availab=
le, Can this be incorprated within HyperNeat?
> >
> > I would like to get a=
 small project test project quickly what is the 
> > best way to go around =
this.
> >
> > Sorry I,m a newbie to this, and would be getting techincal as=
sistance. 
> > But I do understand the external influences of the forex mar=
kets.
> >
> > Thanks
> >
> > Peter
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com <mailto:=
neat%40yahoogroups.com>, Wesley 
> > Tansey <tansey@> wrote:
> > >
> > > Hi=
 Peter,
> > >
> > > I think if you normalize your data (e.g., in the range =
[-1,1]), you can
> > > certainly give it a shot. You need to be careful abo=
ut overfitting to
> > > your data, especially when all you have is daily da=
ta. Also, you 
> > need to
> > > be cautious about the fact that you'd be t=
rading a black box.
> > >
> > > Sounds like a fun project though, best of l=
uck!
> > >
> > > Wesley
> > >
> > > On 11/2/2010 10:08 PM, Peter Henry wrot=
e:
> > > > [Attachment(s) <#TopText> from Peter Henry included below]
> > >=
 > Hi
> > > >
> > > > Refer to excel spreadsheet.
> > > >
> > > > This is w=
hat the data looks like Columns B to F Is the Open High Low
> > > > Close a=
nd Volume of our target Data, Column E is the Close prices 
> > this
> > > =
> is what we are trying to forecast for the following period. Column M
> > =
> > to AP is the Astrological Data that would be used as inputs, Note the
>=
 > > > Astro engine can Generate data indefinitely into the future, this
> =
> > > can be helpful in our forecasts
> > > >
> > > > I hope this is clear
=
> > > > Thanks RegardsPeter
> > > >
> > > >

2010 1:31:05

=

> > > > Thanks for your response. I'm=
 doing it for fun interest and personal

e fascinated by the prospect both Astro 
> > and
> > > > AI working togethe=
r.
> > > >
> > > > The Swiss Astro Engine is freely available and can gener=
ate planetary
> > > > information in real time. I would initially start wit=
h daily price
> > > > data then scale it up to Monthly or Hours and minutes=
.
> > > >
> > > > The inputs is going to be the planetary locations togethe=
r with the
> > > > close prices of target data.
> > > >
> > > > I have all =
the data available in excel format, what the best and
> > > > quickest way =
to carry out some tests?
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > Peter
> > > >

ey Tansey <tansey@>

he
> > > > inputs/outputs going to be? What is your data set size? How are =
you
> > > > going to prevent over-fitting?

impossible to say without knowing more.
> > > > 2. Not theoretically. I sup=
pose at some point, your net gets too slow
> > > > to be practical.

 3. The EPlex C++ framework:
> > > > http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/software.html#=
gaucij_HyperNEAT
> > > > Also, Colin Green's SharpNEAT (C#) framework:
> > =
> > https://sites.google.com/site/sharpneat/
> > > >
> > > > Al! so, are yo=
u doing this for fun or profit? If you're doing it for
> > > > profit, ther=
e are a ton of other considerations that you have to take
> > > > into acco=
unt, particularly regarding trading costs and regulations.
> > > >
> > > > =
Wesley
> > > >
> > > > On 11/2/2010 8:47 PM, Peter Henry wrote:
> > > >
> >=
 > >> Hello,
> > > >>
> > > >> I would like to create trading indicator and=
 systems using 
> > HyperNEAT,
> > > >> input data is going to be fed from =
an Astro Engine, up-to 30 inputs
> > > >> required and one output.
> > > >>=

> > > >> Can someone please answer the following questions or simply give
=
> > > >> there options
> > > >>
> > > >> 1, Does anyone think the HyperNEAT=
 is suitable for such a task
> > > >> 2, Is there any restrictions on the a=
mount of input data that can be
> > > >> used.
> > > >> 3, What is the best=
 HyperNEAT Software Libraries available
> > > >>
> > > >> The engine is goi=
ng to be used for forecast forex prices using Astro
> > > >> and Inter-mark=
et data. HyperNeat to be used to work out 
> > relationships
> > > >> and p=
redict prices,
> > > >>
> > > >> Thanks in advance I will share any results=
 with group
> > > >>
> > > >> Peter
> > > >>
> > > >
> > > >
> > > >
> > >
=
> >
> >
